steps.description: Onsite or virtual assessment workshop where engineers evaluate existing factory automation (e.g., legacy systems), capture KPIs, and define upgrade scope.
steps.businessRationale: A 4-hour workshop is standard for enterprise factory assessments to gather technical constraints and business requirements; faster workshops risk missing critical integration details and reduce conversion probability.

steps.description: Engineering team produces a detailed upgrade design including target PLC/SCADA, drives, network topology, digital twin mapping and BOM for hardware/software.
steps.businessRationale: Comprehensive solution design for industrial automation typically requires multiple engineering hours to ensure compatibility and minimize field rework; accurate design reduces installation time and cost overruns.

steps.description: Contract negotiations including pricing, delivery timelines, support terms, and acceptance criteria; may involve multiple rounds with technical and commercial teams.
steps.businessRationale: Industrial automation contracts are complex due to custom engineering and long-term support requirements; typical negotiation cycles are 4-8 weeks for enterprise accounts to secure optimal terms and minimize project risks.

steps.description: Formal project initiation including team assignments, project charter, milestone planning, risk assessment, and communication protocols setup.
steps.businessRationale: Proper project kickoff reduces scope creep and delivery delays; industrial automation projects benefit from clear governance due to technical complexity and multi-stakeholder coordination requirements.

steps.description: Pre-delivery testing of automation components at manufacturing facility to validate functionality, integration points, and performance against specifications.
steps.businessRationale: Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) is critical for industrial automation to identify issues before site installation; 8-hour FAT sessions are standard for complex systems to minimize costly field modifications.

steps.description: On-site installation of automation equipment including hardware mounting, cable routing, network configuration, and initial system commissioning.
steps.businessRationale: Site installation for factory automation typically requires 2-3 days (16-24 hours) depending on system complexity; proper installation reduces startup time and ensures optimal system performance.

steps.description: Complete system commissioning including process validation, operator training, performance optimization, and handover documentation.
steps.businessRationale: Thorough commissioning ensures system meets performance specifications and operators are competent; 8-hour commissioning is standard for complex automation systems to achieve optimal ROI.
